message_text: Paper Title: Multi-Agent Motion Planning From Signal Temporal Logic Specifications Paper Abstract: We tackle the challenging problem of multi-agent cooperative motion planning for complex tasks described using signal temporal logic (STL), where robots can have nonlinear and nonholonomic dynamics. Existing methods in multi-agent motion planning, especially those based on discrete abstractions and model predictive control (MPC), suffer from limited scalability with respect to the complexity of the task, the size of the workspace, and the planning horizon. We present a method based on timed waypoints to address this issue. We show that timed waypoints can help abstract nonlinear behaviors of the system as safety envelopes around the reference path defined by those waypoints. Then the search for waypoints satisfying the STL specifications can be inductively encoded as a mixed-integer linear program. The agents following the synthesized timed waypoints have their tasks automatically allocated, and are guaranteed to satisfy the STL specifications while avoiding collisions. We evaluate the algorithm on a wide variety of benchmarks. Results show that it supports multi-agent planning from complex specification over long planning horizons, and significantly outperforms state-of-the-art abstraction-based and MPC-based motion planning methods. The implementation is available at https://github.com/sundw2014/STLPlanning . "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Mixed-integer linear programming"

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"lp_solve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lp_solve"},{"title":"Integer linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Integer_linear_programming&redirect=no"}]

## Mixed-Integer Linear Programming

Mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) is a problem where only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers. It's a variant of standard linear programming that combines both continuous and discrete variables.

### Key Characteristics

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem. This contrasts with pure integer linear programs where all variables must be integers.

### Applications

Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. Additional practical applications include:

- Agricultural production planning, involving determining production yield for several crops that can share resources like land, labor, and capital, with the objective of maximizing total production without exceeding available resources.
- Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to routes and equipping them with drivers.
- Frequency planning in GSM mobile networks, which can be formulated as an integer linear program using binary variables.

### Solution Methods

Algorithms for solving MILP include cutting plane methods and branch and bound variants, such as the branch and cut method that combines both approaches.

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Characteristics

The agents in a multi-agent system could be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets.

## Related Research

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 2.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_2.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning configuration space road map path.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_configuration_space_road_map_path.svg"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Topological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_complexity"}]

## Motion Planning - Search Results

Here's an overview of motion planning based on the search results:

### Definition and Core Concept
A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

### Applications
Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

### Key Approaches

**Sampling-Based Algorithms:** Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

**Grid-Based Algorithms:** Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within free space. Search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

### Real-Time Path Planning
Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

### Tools
OMPL (Open Motion Planning Library) is a software package for computing motion plans using sampling-based algorithms.

Web search results for query: "Model Predictive Control"

Links: [{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Predictive control of switching power converters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_control_of_switching_power_converters"},{"title":"System identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_identification"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear-quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Hardware stress test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware_stress_test"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear-quadratic-Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Intermittent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermittent_control"}]

Here's what I found about Model Predictive Control:

## Overview

Model predictive control (MPC) is an advanced method of process control that is used to control a process while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Model predictive controllers rely on dynamic models of the process, most often linear empirical models obtained by system identification.

## History and Applications

It has been in use in the process industries in chemical plants and oil refineries since the 1980s.(no content)In recent years it has also been used in power system balancing models and in power electronics.

## How MPC Works

MPC uses the current plant measurements, the current dynamic state of the process, the MPC models, and the process variable targets and limits to calculate future changes in the dependent variables. These changes are calculated to hold the dependent variables close to target while honoring constraints on both independent and dependent variables.(no content)The MPC typically sends out only the first change in each independent variable to be implemented, and repeats the calculation when the next change is required.

## Model Types

While many real processes are not linear, they can often be considered to be approximately linear over a small operating range. Linear MPC approaches are used in the majority of applications with the feedback mechanism of the MPC compensating for prediction errors due to structural mismatch between the model and the process.

## Classical Examples

Generalized predictive control (GPC) and dynamic matrix control (DMC) are classical examples of MPC.

Links: [{"title":"Nonholonomic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonholonomic_system"},{"title":"Holonomic constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic_constraints"},{"title":"Constraint (mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_(mechanics)"},{"title":"Pfaffian constraint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfaffian_constraint"},{"title":"Chaplygin sleigh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaplygin_sleigh"},{"title":"Holonomic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic"},{"title":"Scleronomous - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scleronomous"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about nonholonomic constraints:

## Definition

A nonholonomic system in classical mechanics is a physical system with some constraints that are impossible to be cast into the form of holonomic constraints. More specifically, they are mechanical systems with constraints on their velocity that are not derivable from position constraints.

## Key Characteristics

The main distinction is that nonholonomic constraints cannot be eliminated by using generalized coordinates, unlike holonomic constraints. A system is a nonholonomic system, if and only if all its constraints are Pfaffian, but some are not integrable.

## Practical Examples

A classic example is a unit sphere rolling without slipping on a plane, where the no-slip condition means that even though there are 5 dimensions of configuration, the velocity at any point in configuration space is restricted to a 2-dimensional subspace.

Another pedagogical example is the Chaplygin sleigh, which consists of a body that slides frictionlessly on a horizontal plane, with a knife edge that constrains its motion so that the knife slides only longitudinally.

## Mathematical Relationship

In general, given a system of constraints, it is nonholonomic if it corresponds to a geometric structure with a connection with nontrivial holonomy group, and vice versa.

Based on the search results, here's information about Signal Temporal Logic:

## Overview

Signal Temporal Logic (STL) is one of several types of temporal logic, which is a formal system used in computer science and logic for reasoning about properties that change over time.

## Context Within Temporal Logic

Temporal logic is a system of rules and symbolism for representing and reasoning about propositions qualified in terms of time. Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware orsoftware systems.

## Relationship to Signals

STL is particularly designed to work with signals. In model checking, a signal or timed state sequence is an extension of the notion of words in a formal language, in which letters are continuously emitted. While a word is traditionally defined as a function from a set of non-negative integers to letters, a signal is a function from a set of real numbers to letters. 

The signal can be analyzed using formal methods to check whether properties hold, with statements typically expressed in metric temporal logic, an extension of linear temporal logic that allows the expression of time constraints.

Signal Temporal Logic is part of a broader family of temporal logics used for specifying and verifying properties of real-time systems and continuous signals.

Links: [{"title":"Traffic collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Carrier-sense multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier-sense_multiple_access_with_collision_avoidance"},{"title":"Airborne collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_Ground_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_Access_with_Collision_Avoidance"},{"title":"Maritime Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (networking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(networking)"},{"title":"Collision avoidance in transportation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_in_transportation"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (spacecraft) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(spacecraft)"}]

Here are the search results for "Collision avoidance":

## Overview

In transportation, collision avoidance is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

## Vehicle/Automotive Systems

A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)Collision avoidance systems range from widespread systems mandatory in some countries, such as automated emergency braking (AEB) in the EU, agreements between carmakers and safety officials to make crash avoidance systems eventually standard, such as in the United States, to research projects including some manufacturer specific devices.

## Aviation Systems

A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of mid-air collision.

## Maritime Systems

Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness. These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence, to issue navigational alerts, assess risks, or initiate corrective actions.

## Networking

In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

## Spacecraft

Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

## Path Planning - Search Results

I found several relevant results about path planning. Here's what path planning encompasses:

### Definition and Overview

Path planning (also known as motion planning or the navigation problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

### Key Applications

For example, a mobile robot navigating inside a building to a distant waypoint would execute this task while avoiding walls and not falling down stairs, with a motion planning algorithm taking a description of these tasks as input and producing the speed and turning commands sent to the robot's wheels.

### Approaches

There are several different strategies for path planning:

- **Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

- **Sampling-based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations, where a basic algorithm samples N configurations and retains those in free space to use as milestones, then constructs a roadmap that connects two milestones if the line segment between them is completely in free space.

- **Real-time Path Planning**: Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, including everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously take in information from the surroundings and create a plan to avoid obstacles.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Multi-Agent Motion Planning From Signal Temporal Logic Specifications". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel method based on timed waypoints for multi-agent motion planning)

**Extracted Triples (7 entities):**

1. **Temporal logic** (concept, uses) - STL is a specialized form of temporal logic
2. **Motion planning** (task, proposes) - The core problem being solved with the new timed waypoints method
3. **Model predictive control** (method, uses) - An existing approach the paper improves upon
4. **Integer programming** (method, uses) - Used to formulate waypoint search as MILP
5. **Multi-agent system** (concept, proposes) - The application domain for cooperative planning
6. **Nonholonomic system** (concept, uses) - Handles robots with nonholonomic dynamics
7. **Collision avoidance system** (task, proposes) - Guaranteed by the proposed method

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script passed successfully. The triples_output.json file is now complete and ready for use.

Sources:
- [Temporal logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic)
- [Motion planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning)
- [Model predictive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control)
- [Integer programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Nonholonomic system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonholonomic_system)
- [Collision avoidance system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system)
